A Year of Labour

Better Britain's look at what changed, what's working or what isn't, and what comes next.

Introduction

Better Britain's 'Year of Labour' report looks at what the Labour government has done since the July 2024 election and what it means for Britain. We aim to be clear, fair and pragmatic. The focus is on real policies and delivery, as they ran and won on a 'change' platform, so we wanted to evaluate that as reasonably as we can.

Each policy is written up in a short, readable format with a score from âˆ’2 to +2. The score is a simple way to show whether early signs are positive, negative or unclear. It can change as new evidence arrives. Claims provide citation links to sources.

Aside from specific policy reviews, we have a general section for errors and oversights, as even without directly affecting policy, optics or related issues can have knock-on effects on the confidence of voters and project stakeholders, like house-builders or business leaders.

Scores Summary

Policy groupScore
Energy, Climate and Nuclear+1.19 from 16 policies
Water and Environmental Regulation+1.00 from 8 policies
Housing and Planning System+0.79 from 14 policies

Digital, Data and AI+1.22 from 9 policies
Devolution, Local Growth and Transport+1.25 from 8 policies
Business Environment and Labour Market+0.82 from 11 policies
Justice, Policing and Prisons+0.17 from 12 policies
Foreign, Defence and Security+0.69 from 13 policies
Culture, Sport and Other Sectors+0.64 from 14 policies
Cross-Cutting Systems and Trade-offs+1.00 from 14 policies
Missed Opportunities, Errors and Governance-1.18 from 11 events
Overall Score
+0.69
Policies: 176 Total score: 121
Each policy is scored from âˆ’2 (harmful) to +2 (very positive).

Latest update (13 Feb 2026)

This report was last updated to 13 February 2026.

In this refresh we added and updated big-ticket items like: clean energy delivery (early Great British Energy rollâ€‘out, new community energy funding, renewables auction results, and the push to speed up grid connections), the governmentâ€™s direction on water reform, major housing and planning changes (including rentersâ€™ rights and planning reforms), new workplace rights and enforcement plans, migration and asylum changes, justice (sentencing reform), and digital rules (digital ID standards and Online Safety enforcement). We also updated the wider â€œmoney and rulesâ€ backdrop â€” the Budget and Finance Bill, plus the UKâ€™s planned carbon border tax â€” and a small number of governance/media events where they could affect delivery.

Labour's score took a small hit (0.72 to 0.69), mainly from drama (lots more resignations). New policies in general have longer horizons, but a few early policies suggest slow progress.

Why this matters

This report was prepared as a reaction to the general level of 'discourse', both online and offline, mainly on the basis that the previous eraâ€™s "everâ€‘crisis" governing style may have shaped not just how we read the news, but how the news is written in the first place. Headlines do not always reflect what is really happening, so we tried to look beyond them to the real underlying policies.

If you want to understand how we score and tag items, see Approach. To dive into the policies, see the policy catalogue. The report includes a brief Conclusion, Glossary and Known Issues.

Approach

We gathered as many Labour policies and meaningful nonâ€‘policy events as we could find since the 2024 general election. Most formal programmes and legislation, plus events and outcomes linked to government decisions, delivery choices or public comms.

The research was organised into policy groups. For each policy or incident, we produced a short policy card entry with a consistent set of fields: the intent(s), the main mechanisms, key claims and evidence, costs and funding, distributional effects, risks and constraints, a brief timeline, and an outcome score.

If you spot something we should correct or expand, please open an issue or pull request on the GitHub repository.

Scoring process

Every card has an outcome score on a simple fiveâ€‘point scale from âˆ’2 to +2. The score is a subjective estimate of the balance of likely benefits and harms. It is not a prediction and it can change over time.

  • +2 - strong/clear positive outcomes, present or very likely.
  • +1 - modest positive outcomes or progress, sometimes with caveats.
  • 0 - unclear or balanced impacts, or too early to tell.
  • âˆ’1 - modest negative outcomes or notable risks outweighing benefits.
  • âˆ’2 - serious negative outcomes or highâ€‘risk decisions/costs with little offsetting value.

All scores remain open to revision as new evidence arrives or different perspectives are offered.

Scoring consistency

A broader range of scores was considered, and would express more nuance in complex issues, but assigning a subjective score to every policy means we make decisions about which influences/outcomes are more important than others. A narrow range keeps the system simple and clear.

A weighted approach was also considered (is nuclear energy capacity more or less important than consistent building regulations around single-sex spaces?), but that very quickly shows limitations, and enhances bias. We're not trying to make any one perspective more important than any other, but to consider the overall effects of decisions made and the plans laid out.

We also considered testing policy performance against Conservative policies of the last few years (with post-COVID as the primary timespan), but the noise level in reporting was WAY too high, it just didn't have enough comparable policy to bother.

Our scoring is intended to be seen as comparable to better or worse governance outcomes, reducing the overall potential range lets us define how broad this scale could be. Practically, our scale runs from "the worst any government could be expected to do" to "the best any government could be expected to do".

Taxonomy and tags

To make the content filterable and to keep the writeâ€‘ups short, we use a small set of tags. Expand for details. Impact quality describes how confident we are in a claim:
  • âœ… [impact-proven] is supported by direct evidence, delivered outputs or robust evaluation.
  • â†— [impact-likely] has strong rationale and early indicators but needs time to confirm.
  • â—‡ [impact-hypothetical] is a plausible mechanism with little or no current evidence.
  • ï¼Ÿ [unknown] flags a material uncertainty or missing data.
  • ğŸ’¬ [opinion] marks a clearly interpretive statement.

Areas of effect help group by domain. Common examples include: âš¡ [area: energy], ğŸ’§ [area: water], ğŸ  [area: housing], ğŸ—º [area: planning], ğŸ¥ [area: nhs], ğŸ§‘â€âš•ï¸ [area: social-care], ğŸ‘ª [area: welfare], ğŸ“ [area: education], ğŸ§° [area: skills], ğŸ›‚ [area: migration], âš– [area: justice], Â£ [area: economy], ğŸ§¾ [area: fiscal], ğŸ› [area: devolution], ğŸ’» [area: digital], ğŸ¤– [area: ai], ğŸŒ¿ [area: environment], ğŸ¢ [area: business], ğŸ‘· [area: labour-market], ğŸš† [area: transport], ğŸ­ [area: culture], ğŸŒ [area: foreign], ğŸ›¡ [area: defence].

Time horizons describe when effects should become visible: â± [horizon: short] (under 1 year), â³ [horizon: medium] (1â€“3 years), and ğŸ•° [horizon: long] (over 3 years).

Distributional tags highlight who is most affected. For example: ğŸ’· [dist: low-income], ğŸ‘µ [dist: pensioners], ğŸ”‘ [dist: renters], ğŸ¡ [dist: homeowners], ğŸª [dist: SMEs], ğŸ¢ [dist: large-firms], and regional tags like ğŸ“ [dist: regions:Greater Manchester].

Risk and uncertainty tags call out the main constraints. We use âš– [risk: legal], ğŸ— [risk: delivery], Â£ [risk: finance], ğŸ› [risk: political] and ğŸ“Š [risk: data-gap] to signpost what might go wrong or what we do not yet know.

Cards also have a small â€œmeta lineâ€ under the title. Common tags there include: âœ… [status: enacted] / ğŸ›  [status: programme], ğŸ› [lead: department/body], ğŸ“… [start: YYYY-MM], and (again) the time horizon tags above.

Citations and references

We use inline footnotes for every material claim: [^id]. The page renderer pulls all citations together so all evidenced claims should have links that inform the claim. You can toggle on/off the full titles of those links here.

Style and voice

We aim for clarity over jargon, short paragraphs over dense blocks, and concrete examples over abstract claims. We focus on people and outcomes. See the Writing Voice & Style guide for more detail on tone and presentation.

Roadmap and open questions

Two nearâ€‘term improvements are on the list.

  • Ratings will be adjusted over time, and while updates will be limited (maybe quarterly), this report will develop into an ongoing 'report card' for Labour's government over time.
    • The next update will probably start by renaming the report
  • Filtering/sorting based on tags of various types might be useful.
    • Policy cards take up a lot of the viewport, maybe field-toggles and a table view will help
  • The citation toggle should be easier to use during scroll

2.0 â€” Conclusions

Looking mainly at policy, the Labour government's first year looks pretty healthy, with caveats. Some removals of bad policies from the previous government, some inherited programmes carried over the line, lots of sensible new programmes, and some optimism on the longer horizons. Finally, a national wealth fund that has the 'promise' of adding strong income entries to the budget and a realistic plan for net-zero, that also strengthens national security. Welfare is clearly struggling, where longer term changes may be better brought forward, and leaning on the 'black hole' in the finances has 'felt' like an old line for a while already, even if there's some justification for it.

Minor optics drama and limited scandals compared to the previous government, but cases can be made from either position for many controversial decisions. Better decisions could have been made generally, especially on order of events, cancelling welfare systems before better schemes were in place, or making statements that were then rolled back because of pressure. Impact: hypothetical U-turns are bad for stability, but generally good for outcomes, even if it puts some artificial limits on other options. There's also debate to be had on the limitations of current fiscal policy, but some legislative steps (and more to be expected) can mitigate some of the harm of those restrictions.

Better Britain would like to see clearer communication, especially on more complex or long-term policies, and more cohesion to keep drama from turning into yet more PR crises. This government often chooses to drop problematic individuals, perhaps out of a fear of optics, while they have a pretty strong policy base to build on and should be championing it openly instead of chasing the news cycle and responding to drama with reshuffles that risk overturning the cart. There's more research to be done on press coverage and public opinion, but this Better Britain Bureau policy-review concludes: 'Not that bad', C+.

The complete set of policies considered follows...

2.1 â€” Energy, Climate and Nuclear

Scope: Great British Energy (GBE); faster renewables; grid reform; cleaner homes; integrated nuclear and small modular reactors (SMRs).

Great British Energy (GBE)

Status: enacted Lead: DESNZ/GBE Start: 2025-05 Horizon: long

Intent (plain language): Create a publicly owned cleanâ€‘power developer to speed up building strategic projects and bring in private investment. â†—Great British Energy Act 2025.

Mechanism(s): Primary legislation; a stateâ€‘owned company with an investment mandate; joint ventures (JVs); participation in Contracts for Difference (CfD) and partnerships. â†—Great British Energy Act 2025. â†—Great British Energy Act 2025: factsheet.

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: proven Area: energy Horizon: short Company established with interim board/CEO; initial local solar programme launched. â†—Great British Energy Act 2025: factsheet.
  • Impact: proven Area: energy Horizon: short Early publicâ€‘estate delivery: solar rollout announced for NHS sites to cut bills (multiâ€‘site programme with a published expansion path). â†—Great British Energy starts rolling out solar for NHS sites to cut bills â€” GOV.UK (24 Oct 2025). â†—Great British Energy (GBE) â€” NHS sites cut bills: Great British Energy solar panels (blog).
  • Impact: likely Area: energy Horizon: medium Pipeline identified, subject to final investment decisions (FIDs) and grid connection slots. â†—Great British Energy â€” role/pipeline in Clean Energy Industries Sector Plan.
  • Unknown Grid connection timings and supply chain constraints. â†—Ofgem â€” Connections End-to-End Review: Consultation (Nov 2024).

Costs & funding: Initial capital envelope Â£8.3bn (public) to mobilise ~Â£30-60bn private; returns long-dated. â†—Great British Energy founding statement.

Distributional effects: Regional jobs in manufacturing/construction; community energy participation. â†—The Guardian â€” National Wealth Fund overview and investment focus.

Risks & constraints: Risk: deliveryRisk: finance Supply chain; planning and environmental consents; cost of capital. â†—Lessons learned: private finance for infrastructure.

Timeline & milestones: 2025: Royal Assent (RA) and standâ€‘up; 2025â€“26: first JV commitments; 2026+: scaleâ€‘up. â†—Great British Energy Act 2025: factsheet.

Outcome score: +2 â€” Structural enabler with early delivery steps.

Local Power Plan (Local/Communityâ€‘Owned Clean Energy)

Status: programme Lead: DESNZ/GBE Start: 2026-02 Horizon: medium

Intent (plain language): Make it easier for communities and local areas to own and benefit from cleanâ€‘energy generation â€” and scale projects that are â€œsmall individually, big in aggregateâ€. â†—Local Power Plan â€” GOV.UK (10 Feb 2026).

Mechanism(s): Up to Â£1bn in support; programme support to improve local/project capability; standardised delivery approaches and business models; coordination with grid/planning and national programmes. â†—Local Power Plan â€” GOV.UK (10 Feb 2026). â†—Community energy revolution gets Â£1bn boost as Great British Energy Local Power Plan unveiled â€” GOV.UK (10 Feb 2026).

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: likely Area: energy Horizon: medium Government frames the plan as a major scale-up of local/community energy, aiming to accelerate deployment and local participation. â†—Community energy revolution gets Â£1bn boost as Great British Energy Local Power Plan unveiled â€” GOV.UK (10 Feb 2026).
  • Unknown Gridâ€‘connection constraints and local delivery capacity could cap nearâ€‘term takeâ€‘up without parallel â€œsystemâ€ reform. â†—Ofgem â€” Connections End-to-End Review: Consultation (Nov 2024).

Costs & funding: Up to Â£1bn (programme envelope), with final allocation and instruments determining value-for-money. â†—Community energy revolution gets Â£1bn boost as Great British Energy Local Power Plan unveiled â€” GOV.UK (10 Feb 2026).

Distributional effects: Potentially higher local acceptance and a clearer â€œshare of benefitsâ€ for host communities; impacts depend on governance and who can participate. â†—Local Power Plan â€” GOV.UK (10 Feb 2026).

Risks & constraints: Risk: deliveryRisk: equity Complex project finance and volunteer capacity; risk that betterâ€‘resourced areas capture disproportionate benefits unless access is designed in. â†—Local Power Plan â€” GOV.UK (10 Feb 2026).

Timeline & milestones: Plan published Feb 2026; programme rollout and funding decisions staged through 2026+. â†—Local Power Plan â€” GOV.UK (10 Feb 2026).

Outcome score: +1 â€” Highâ€‘potential local enabler if simplified and properly supported; impact depends on execution and grid access.

National Wealth Fund (energy-relevant)

Status: programme Lead: HMT/UKIB/NWF Start: 2024-11 Horizon: long

Intent (plain language): Public coâ€‘investment to bring in private money for clean energy and supporting supply chains. â†—The Guardian â€” What is the National Wealth Fund and what will it invest in?

Mechanism(s): Capitalising the UK Infrastructure Bank (UKIB); equity and debt instruments; strategic forums with public investors. â†—HM Treasury annual report and accounts 2023 to 2024.

Key claims & evidence:

2.2 â€” Water and Environmental Regulation

Scope: Cleaning up rivers and beaches; tougher regulation of water companies; investment, enforcement, and transparency.

Water (Special Measures) Act 2025 â€” Implementation

Status: enacted Lead: DEFRA/Ofwat/Environment Agency Start: 2025-05 Horizon: medium

Intent (plain language): Give regulators sharper tools to stop sewage pollution and poor service, and to make company bosses personally accountable. â†—DEFRA â€” Water (Special Measures) Bill/Act measures and enforcement powers.

Mechanism(s): Primary legislation; Ofwat directions; Environment Agency (EA) enforcement powers; bonus-ban powers for failing firms; civil penalty thresholds and automatic sanctions. â†—DEFRA â€” Water (Special Measures) Bill/Act measures and enforcement powers.

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: proven Area: water Horizon: short Executive bonuses have been banned at multiple worst-performing companies (including Thames and Yorkshire Water). â†—DEFRA â€” Ban on bonuses for executives at failing water companies (policy and directions).
  • Impact: proven Area: environment Horizon: short Record penalties issued for spills and unlawful dividend practices (e.g., Â£122.7m for Thames Water). â†—Reuters â€” Thames Water, battling to avoid administration, agrees fine payment plan â€”
  • Impact: likely Area: environment Horizon: medium Real-time monitoring and automatic fines are expected to cut routine sewage discharges. â†—Environment Agency â€” Event Duration Monitoring (EDM) guidance and data.
  • Unknown The size of bill impacts from compliance costs depends on how efficiently companies deliver upgrades. â†—Ofwat/CCW â€” Average water bills 2025/26; lessons from PR24.

Costs & funding: Company-funded upgrades; fines and penalties ring-fenced for cleanup projects; hardship support to be protected in company plans. â†—Ofwat/CCW â€” Average water bills 2025/26; lessons from PR24.

Distributional effects: Cleaner rivers benefit all users; near-term bill pressure could hit low-income households unless social tariffs and support schemes are strengthened. â†—CCW â€” What we learned from PR24 (distributional impacts).

Risks & constraints: Risk: delivery Complex engineering works; Risk: finance highly leveraged company balance sheets; Risk: legal potential challenges to penalties/bonus bans. â†—NAO â€” Regulating for investment and outcomes in the water sector (Apr 2025).

Timeline & milestones: Act in force 2025; bonus-ban directions summer 2025; updated company plans and new penalty schedule through 2025â€“26. â†—DEFRA â€” Water (Special Measures) Bill/Act measures and enforcement powers.

Outcome score: +2 â€” Stronger accountability with early visible enforcement; watch delivery and bill impacts.

Ofwat Price Review (PR24) â€” 2025â€“2030 Settlements

Status: enacted Lead: Ofwat Start: 2025-04 Horizon: medium

Intent (plain language): Approve multi-year investment to modernise pipes and treatment works, while setting limits on bills and service standards across 2025â€“2030. â†—Ofwat â€” PR24 final determinations overview.

Mechanism(s): Regulatory price control (PR24): capital programmes, performance commitments (leakage, pollution), outcome delivery incentives (rewards/penalties). â†—Ofwat â€” PR24 framework and methodology.

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: proven Area: environment Horizon: medium Around Â£104 billion across 2025â€“30 for upgrades, including storm-overflow storage and treatment capacity. â†—Ofwat â€” PR24 final determinations overview.

Risks & constraints: Risk: delivery Supply chain capacity and skilled labour; Risk: finance higher interest rates; Risk: political bill acceptability. â†—NAO â€” Regulating for investment and outcomes in the water sector (Apr 2025).

Environment Agency Enforcement â€” Polluters Pay

Status: programme Lead: Environment Agency (EA)/DEFRA Start: 2025-04 Horizon: short

Mechanism(s): Expanded inspection teams; expedited civil sanctions; criminal prosecutions for serious and persistent breaches; cost recovery from offenders. â†—Environment Agency â€” Enforcement and sanctions approach (water pollution).

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: proven Area: environment Horizon: short More live criminal investigations at underperforming companies; rapid fixed penalties for minor, repeated breaches. â†—Environment Agency â€” Enforcement and prosecutions: annual statistics (latest).
  • Impact: likely Area: water Horizon: short Transparent publication of incidents and enforcement outcomes increases deterrence. â†—Environment Agency â€” Event Duration Monitoring (EDM) guidance and data.
  • Unknown Prosecution backlogs and court capacity could slow cases. â†—Polluting water bosses face up to two years in prison.

Costs & funding: Funded by DEFRA settlement; fine revenues directed to environmental improvements; polluter-pays cost recovery. â†—Reuters â€” UK to set out water reforms as Thames Water faces crisis â€”

Distributional effects: Local communities near affected rivers get targeted cleanup projects; long-term health and recreation benefits. â†—The Guardian â€” Rescue plan at Thames Water is still too murky â€”

Risks & constraints: Risk: legal Litigation risk from companies; Risk: delivery forensic evidence and lab capacity; Risk: political perceived inconsistency across regions. â†—NAO â€” Regulating for investment and outcomes in the water sector (Apr 2025).

Timeline & milestones: Enhanced enforcement guidance issued 2025; quarterly enforcement bulletins; annual progress review. â†—Environment Agency â€” Enforcement and sanctions approach (water pollution).

Outcome score: +1 â€” Visible enforcement ups the pressure; court throughput is the main constraint.

Redirecting Water Company Fines to Local-Led Restoration

Status: administrative Lead: DEFRA/Environment Agency Start: 2026-01 Horizon: short

Mechanism(s): Ring-fencing and allocating fine/penalty revenues to eligible local restoration programmes (with delivery routes via agencies and local groups), alongside existing polluterâ€‘pays enforcement. â†—Millions in water company fines to power local-led restoration â€” GOV.UK (20 Jan 2026).

  • Impact: likely Area: environment Horizon: short More visible local restoration could strengthen public trust that enforcement translates into improvements. â†—Millions in water company fines to power local-led restoration â€” GOV.UK (20 Jan 2026).
  • Unknown Whether revenues are additional to (or substitute for) baseline environmental budgets, and how consistently funds reach the worstâ€‘affected catchments. â†—Millions in water company fines to power local-led restoration â€” GOV.UK (20 Jan 2026).

Storm Overflow Reduction Programme â€” Monitoring & Targets

Status: programme Lead: Ofwat/EA/Water Companies Start: 2025-01 Horizon: medium

Intent (plain language): Cut raw sewage spills into rivers and seas, with full monitoring, public transparency, and deadlines to halve spills by 2030. â†—GOV.UK â€” Storm Overflows Discharge Reduction Plan.

Mechanism(s): Mandatory event duration monitors (EDMs) on all overflows; near-real-time publication; new storage and treatment capacity; performance targets with penalties. â†—Environment Agency â€” Event Duration Monitoring (EDM) guidance and data.

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: proven Area: transparency Horizon: short Monitoring now covers almost all overflows, with public data feeds. â†—Environment Agency â€” Event Duration Monitoring (EDM) guidance and data.
  • Impact: likely Area: environment Horizon: medium Storage, screening, and treatment upgrades reduce spill frequency and duration. â†—Ofwat â€” PR24 final determinations overview.
  • Unknown Extreme rainfall events could mask progress year-to-year; long time-series needed. â†—Met Office â€” State of the UK Climate 2024/25 (rainfall context).

Costs & funding: Included within PR24 capex; penalties for missed targets cannot be recouped from customers. â†—Ofwat â€” PR24 framework and methodology.

Distributional effects: Cleaner bathing waters and amenity value for coastal and river communities; construction disruption near assets. â†—The Guardian â€” Rescue plan at Thames Water is still too murky â€”

Risks & constraints: Risk: delivery Gridlocked planning for large tanks/tunnels; Risk: finance contractor costs; Risk: legal permits and consents. â†—Planning (infrastructure/water) â€” consents and delivery constraints (context note).

Timeline & milestones: 100% monitoring coverage targeted; interim spill reduction checkpoints 2027; at least 50% reduction by 2030. â†—GOV.UK â€” Storm Overflows Discharge Reduction Plan.

Outcome score: +2 â€” Clear plan with transparency and penalties; delivery is hard but benefits are broad.

A New Vision for Water â€” White Paper and Reform Bill Direction

Status: programme Lead: DEFRA Start: 2026-01 Horizon: long

Intent (plain language): Overhaul how the water system is regulated and held accountable, so pollution reduction, investment delivery and customer service are governed as one coherent system. â†—A New Vision for Water: White Paper â€” GOV.UK (Jan 2026).

Mechanism(s): White Paper setting out a reform programme and legislative direction (including a proposed single regulator approach), plus a future water reform bill to implement structural changes. â†—A New Vision for Water: White Paper â€” GOV.UK (Jan 2026). â†—Government unveils biggest overhaul to water in a generation â€” GOV.UK (19 Jan 2026).

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: likely Area: governance Horizon: medium White Paper proposes a more unified regulatory model (including ending Ofwatâ€™s current standâ€‘alone role) to reduce duplication and clarify accountability. â†—A New Vision for Water: White Paper â€” GOV.UK (Jan 2026).
  • Unknown Whether structural reform improves outcomes without disrupting enforcement/investment during transition; timetable depends on legislation and institutional design. â†—A New Vision for Water: White Paper â€” GOV.UK (Jan 2026).

Costs & funding: One-off transition costs for institutional change; potential medium-term efficiencies from shared data and joined-up enforcement/price control. â†—A New Vision for Water: White Paper â€” GOV.UK (Jan 2026).

Distributional effects: If it improves service and reduces pollution, benefits are broad; transition risks (and any bill impacts) would be felt unevenly by region and by low-income households without adequate social tariffs. â†—A New Vision for Water: White Paper â€” GOV.UK (Jan 2026).

Risks & constraints: Risk: legalRisk: delivery Legislative time and design complexity; risk of scope creep; risk of losing specialist capabilities during reorganisation. â†—A New Vision for Water: White Paper â€” GOV.UK (Jan 2026).

Timeline & milestones: White Paper published Jan 2026; next steps depend on consultation and bill timing. â†—A New Vision for Water: White Paper â€” GOV.UK (Jan 2026).

Outcome score: +1 â€” High-leverage governance fix if executed cleanly; risk is transition disruption without clearer outcomes.

Unified Water Regulator â€” Proposal to Merge Functions

Status: programme Lead: DEFRA Start: 2025-07 Horizon: long

Intent (plain language): End the â€œblame gameâ€ between agencies by creating a single, accountable regulator for water quality, customer service, and investment. â†—Reuters â€” UK to create new water regulator amid crisis at Thames Water â€”

Mechanism(s): Policy proposal for legislation: bring together Ofwat (economic regulator), the Environment Agencyâ€™s water functions (environmental enforcement), Natural England (ecology advice), and the Drinking Water Inspectorate (safety), into one body. â†—Reuters â€” UK to create new water regulator amid crisis at Thames Water â€” â†—A New Vision for Water: White Paper â€” GOV.UK (Jan 2026).

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: likely Area: governance Horizon: medium One regulator reduces duplication and speeds decisions; clearer accountability for outcomes. â†—IFG - House of Lords Reform.
  • Impact: likely Area: governance Horizon: medium The 2026 White Paper reinforces the direction of travel toward a single-regulator model and a formal water reform bill. â†—A New Vision for Water: White Paper â€” GOV.UK (Jan 2026).
  • Unknown Transition costs, staffing transfers, and statutory powers until legislation passes. â†—Reuters â€” UK to create new water regulator amid crisis at Thames Water â€”

Costs & funding: One-off transition costs; expected efficiencies from shared data and enforcement teams; funding model to be set in the bill. â†—Reuters â€” UK to create new water regulator amid crisis at Thames Water â€”

Distributional effects: Simpler contact point for customers and local groups; potential short-term disruption during merger. â†—CCW â€” What we learned from PR24 (distributional impacts).

Risks & constraints: Risk: legal Legislative time; Risk: delivery moving staff and systems; Risk: political scope creep and independence concerns. â†—IFG - House of Lords Reform.

Timeline & milestones: Consultation and development work 2025; White Paper Jan 2026 sets direction; draft bill preparation and staged transition after Royal Assent. â†—A New Vision for Water: White Paper â€” GOV.UK (Jan 2026). â†—Reuters â€” UK to create new water regulator amid crisis at Thames Water â€”

Outcome score: +1 â€” Governance fix with promise, but depends on a good bill and careful transition.

High Value Council Tax Surcharge (England, Â£2m+ homes)

Mechanism(s): New surcharge design and implementation parameters published by government for eligible properties above a value threshold (with operational detail via council tax administration). â†—High value council tax surcharge â€” GOV.UK (26 Nov 2025).

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: likely Area: fiscal Horizon: short Concentrates additional tax on a small share of the housing stock; yields depend on valuation approach and behavioural response. â†—High value council tax surcharge â€” GOV.UK (26 Nov 2025).
  • Unknown Distributional and market effects (e.g., avoidance, revaluation disputes, or impacts on high-end transactions). â†—High value council tax surcharge â€” GOV.UK (26 Nov 2025).

Costs & funding: Administrative implementation and valuation/appeals capacity; revenues depend on final design. â†—High value council tax surcharge â€” GOV.UK (26 Nov 2025).

Distributional effects: More progressive property-tax incidence; may be geographically concentrated in London and certain high-value markets. â†—High value council tax surcharge â€” GOV.UK (26 Nov 2025).

Risks & constraints: Risk: legalRisk: delivery Valuation disputes and gaming; fairness perceptions; interaction with wider property tax reform debates. â†—High value council tax surcharge â€” GOV.UK (26 Nov 2025).

Timeline & milestones: Policy paper published Nov 2025; implementation timing depends on secondary changes and local billing cycles. â†—High value council tax surcharge â€” GOV.UK (26 Nov 2025).

Outcome score: 0 â€” Potentially progressive, but outcomes depend on design details and enforcement.

NHS Recovery: Cutting Waiting Times and Backlogs

Status: programme Lead: DHSC/NHS England Start: 2024-07 Horizon: medium

Intent: Bring down hospital waiting lists and speed up treatment, so more people are seen within target times in planned (elective) care and emergency departments. â†—Major plan to recover urgent and emergency care services. NHS England â€“ outlined measures to cut waiting times in A&E and elective care so more patients are seen within target times.

Mechanism(s): Extra operating lists (evenings/weekends), surgical hubs, community diagnostic centres, targeted funding for high-volume specialties, and operational grip on A&E standards. â†—NHS England â€” NHS delivers record numbers of treatments as waiting list drops to 26-month low â€”

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: proven Area: nhs Horizon: short Overall waiting list edged down to ~7.36 million by late spring 2025, with record monthly elective activity (about 1.5 million treatments in May). â†—NHS backlog data analysis. British Medical Association â€“ notes the RTT waiting list fell to ~7.36 million by mid-2025, and a record ~1.5 million elective treatments were delivered in May 2025.
  • Impact: proven Area: nhs Horizon: short Emergency departments saw the best fourâ€‘hour performance since 2021 after targeted recovery actions. â†—NHS England â€” Urgent and Emergency Care (UEC) hub.
  • Unknown Sustaining the pace depends on winter pressures, workforce supply, and theatre capacity. â†—NHS England's management of elective care transformation programmes.

Costs & funding: Multiâ€‘year Elective Recovery Plan funding (~Â£8bn over the period), plus capital for surgical hubs and diagnostics. â†—NHS England â€” NHS delivers record numbers of treatments as waiting list drops to 26-month low â€”

Distributional effects: Faster treatment benefits patients nationwide; biggest gains expected where hubs and diagnostic centres are concentrated. â†—Government to deliver 160 community diagnostic centres a year early. GOV.UK (Press release, Department of Health and Social Care).

Risks & constraints: Risk: delivery Theatre staffing, bed availability, winter spikes. Risk: capital Backlog of estates upgrades. â†—Fixing public services: The NHS.

Timeline & milestones: 2024â€“25: ramp elective volumes and diagnostics; 2026: embed sustained RTT improvements; ongoing A&E performance recovery. â†—Major plan to recover urgent and emergency care services. NHS England â€“ outlined measures to cut waiting times in A&E and elective care so more patients are seen within target times.

Outcome score: +1 â€” Clear progress visible, with risks around sustaining throughput.

Model Emergency Department â€” High-Performing Urgent and Emergency Care Pathways

Distributional effects: Benefits older people and carers; helps hospitals by reducing bed blocking. â†—Rapid evaluation: hospital discharge funding 2022 to 2023. GOV.UK (Research and analysis, Department of Health and Social Care) â€“ found discharge fund increased discharges and reduced delays.

Risks & constraints: Risk: workforce Care worker shortages and turnover; Risk: finance council budgets under strain. â†—IFS â€” Adult social care in England: what next?

Timeline & milestones: 2024â€“26: stabilisation and integration actions; later decisions on charging caps/timelines. â†—DHSC â€” Adult social care policy collection (market sustainability, discharge).

Outcome score: +1 â€” Practical steps that help now; structural issues still to fix.

2.5 â€” Welfare and Inequality

Scope: Family incomes; poverty drivers; in-kind supports.

Two-Child Limit in Family Benefits â€” retained, with repeal bill introduced

Status: administrative+bill-in-train Lead: DWP/HMT Start: 2017; update 2026-01 Horizon: medium

Intent (plain language): Maintain the existing rule that limits support to the first two children in most lowâ€‘income families (as a costâ€‘control measure), while also putting a removal proposal into Parliament that would end the cap if it passes. â†—House of Commons Library â€” The two-child limit in universal credit and child tax credit. â†—Universal Credit (Removal of Two Child Limit) Bill â€” UK Parliament Bills (introduced 8 Jan 2026).

Mechanism(s): Rule remains in Child Tax Credit and the child elements of Universal Credit; a bill has been introduced to repeal/modify the twoâ€‘child limit within Universal Credit (with operational detail depending on commencement rules and any transitional arrangements). â†—GOV.UK â€” Child Tax Credit and Universal Credit: claimants with more than 2 children (exceptions guidance). â†—Universal Credit (Removal of Two Child Limit) Bill â€” UK Parliament Bills (introduced 8 Jan 2026).

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: proven Area: welfare Horizon: short Around 1.6â€“1.7 million children are in families affected, raising measured child poverty particularly for larger families. â†—Resolution Foundation â€” Living Standards Outlook 2025 (child poverty analysis).
  • Impact: proven Area: welfare Horizon: short Retention prevents large upfront Exchequer cost but deepens poverty for affected households. â†—IFS â€” What would VAT on private school fees raise?
  • Impact: likely Area: welfare Horizon: medium A bill to remove the twoâ€‘child limit has been introduced, but the rule remains in force unless and until legislation passes. â†—Universal Credit (Removal of Two Child Limit) Bill â€” UK Parliament Bills (introduced 8 Jan 2026). â†—House of Commons Library â€” The two-child limit in universal credit and child tax credit.

Costs & funding: Retention avoids several Â£ billions of additional annual spend relative to repeal; removing the limit would create a material recurring fiscal cost (subject to final scope and commencement). â†—IFS â€” What would VAT on private school fees raise? â†—Universal Credit (Removal of Two Child Limit) Bill â€” UK Parliament Bills (introduced 8 Jan 2026).

Distributional effects: Concentrated losses for lowâ€‘income families with three or more children; strongest poverty impact in some regions and minority communities. â†—Resolution Foundation â€” Living Standards Outlook 2025 (child poverty analysis).

Risks & constraints: Risk: financeRisk: political Fiscal headroom tradeâ€‘offs; sustained criticism from antiâ€‘poverty groups; Risk: data-gap need for upâ€‘toâ€‘date cohort impact estimates and clarity on transitional/backdating decisions if repeal proceeds. â†—Two-child limit statistics: new breakdowns show how the policy falls hardest on disadvantaged groups. â†—Universal Credit (Removal of Two Child Limit) Bill â€” UK Parliament Bills (introduced 8 Jan 2026).

Timeline & milestones: Maintained through 2024â€“25; repeal bill introduced Jan 2026; timing depends on parliamentary passage and commencement. â†—Universal Credit (Removal of Two Child Limit) Bill â€” UK Parliament Bills (introduced 8 Jan 2026). â†—House of Commons Library â€” The two-child limit in universal credit and child tax credit.

Outcome score: 1 â€” Twoâ€‘child limit repeal is at least on a legislative track.

Universal Credit (Adjustment) Act â€” Base Rate Up, Health Element Rebalanced

Status: enacted Lead: HMT/DWP Start: 2025-03 Horizon: medium

Intent (plain language): Raise the basic Universal Credit amount for everyone, while changing the extra disabilityâ€‘related topâ€‘up for new claims to focus higher support on those with the most severe, longâ€‘term conditions. â†—Welfare bill will protect the most vulnerable and help households with income boost.

Mechanism(s): Primary legislation; commencement from April 2026 for new healthâ€‘related claims; transitional protections for existing claimants with severe or lifelong conditions. â†—Spring Statement 2025 health and disability benefit reforms â€“ Equality Analysis.

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: proven Area: welfare Horizon: short Basic UC standard allowance increased above previous path. â†—Great British Energy Bill 2024-25.
  • Impact: likely Area: welfare Horizon: medium New health element around half the previous rate for most new claims, with protections for the severest cases. â†—Welfare bill will protect the most vulnerable and help households with income boost.
  • Unknown Employment effects for people with fluctuating conditions; monitoring required. â†—Changes to the Universal Credit and Personal Independence Payment Bill mean no savings for the Chancellor in this Parliament.

Costs & funding: Net savings by 2029â€“30 versus previous policy due to health element changes; partâ€‘recycled into employment support offers. â†—OBR â€” Economic and Fiscal Outlook, March 2025 (policy costings).

Distributional effects: Many without disabilities gain from higher base rate; future new disabled claimants with moderate needs receive less than before; those with the highest needs protected. â†—Spring Statement 2025 health and disability benefit reforms â€“ Equality Analysis.

Risks & constraints: Risk: delivery Complexity of assessments and transitions; Risk: political perceived cuts for some new claimants. â†—Changes to the Universal Credit and Personal Independence Payment Bill mean no savings for the Chancellor in this Parliament.

Timeline & milestones: Royal Assent 2025; April 2026 start for new healthâ€‘related claims; independent PIP review to inform future alignment. â†—Welfare bill will protect the most vulnerable and help households with income boost.

Outcome score: 0 â€” Balanced: higher base support vs reduced future topâ€‘ups for some disabled newcomers.

Personal Independence Payment (PIP) â€” Reform Paused and Independent Review

Universal Credit Administration â€” Debt Deductions and Reassessments

Winter Fuel Payment â€” Cut, Backlash and Targeted Reversal

  • Unknown Longerâ€‘term policy direction for universal vs targeted pensioner support. â†—Changes to Winter Fuel Payment eligibility rules.

Risks & constraints: Risk: political Optics of Uâ€‘turn; Risk: fiscal pressure on other budgets. â†—Expanding winter fuel payment eligibility.

Outcome score: âˆ’1 â€” Poorly sequenced; reversal limits harm but adds fiscal pressure.

2.6 â€” Education and Skills

Scope: School system funding; private-to-state movement; teacher workforce; childcare; skills and apprenticeships; higher education pressures; curriculum and standards; safeguarding guidance.

VAT on Private School Fees and Removal of Rates Relief

Status: enacted Lead: HM Treasury / Department for Education Start: 2025-01 Horizon: medium

Intent: Raise money for state education and reduce unfair tax advantages for private (independent) schools by charging Value Added Tax (VAT) on fees and removing business rates relief. â†—VAT policy overview (DfE/HMT).

Mechanism(s): Budget measures and secondary legislation: 20% VAT applied to most fees from Jan 2025; charitable business rates relief removed from April 2025. â†—Finance/secondary legislation text.

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: proven Area: education Horizon: short Private school rolls fell by roughly 1.9% midâ€‘year (â‰ˆ10â€“11k pupils), with dozens of small schools announcing closures/mergers; state capacity absorbed most leavers so far. â†—Explore Education Statistics â€” Schools, pupils and their characteristics. â†—Independent Schools Council â€” Annual Census 2025.
  • Impact: likely Area: education Horizon: medium Policy expected to raise â‰ˆÂ£1.7bn per year to fund teachers, free school meals, and breakfast clubs. â†—OBR â€” Economic and fiscal outlook: November 2024 (policy measures and costings).
  • Unknown Localised pressure in already full state schools; uneven effects by region. â†—DfE â€” Basic need allocations (local authority allocations and guidance).

Costs & funding: New revenue recycled to education; transition grants available for local authorities to handle hotspots. â†—Ending tax breaks for private schools: Technical note on VAT and business rates.

Distributional effects: Benefits the 90%+ of children in state schools; higher costs for some private school families; closure risk concentrated in smaller schools. â†—IFS â€” What would VAT on private school fees raise?

Risks & constraints: Risk: delivery Managing intake in oversubscribed areas; Risk: political public debate on fairness; Risk: data-gap timely tracking of transfers. â†—House of Commons Library â€” Changes to benefits for disabled people (CBP-10283).

Timeline & milestones: VAT in force Jan 2025; rates relief removal from Apr 2025; first full-year outturns in 2025/26. â†—Finance/secondary legislation text.

Outcome score: +1 â€” Additional funding for state pupils with manageable system pressures so far.

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: likely Area: nhs Horizon: long A clearer training priority framework could support workforce sustainability, but effects take years to materialise. â†—Medical Training (Prioritisation) Bill â€” UK Parliament Bills (introduced 13 Jan 2026).
  • Unknown Interaction with existing NHS workforce plans, placement capacity, and funding for medical school and foundation training. â†—Medical Training (Prioritisation) Bill â€” UK Parliament Bills (introduced 13 Jan 2026).

Costs & funding: Training expansion requires sustained education and placement funding; costs are frontâ€‘loaded with longâ€‘run returns via staffing stability. â†—Medical Training (Prioritisation) Bill â€” UK Parliament Bills (introduced 13 Jan 2026).

Distributional effects: Potential benefits for underserved regions if training places and placements are targeted; risk of concentration in already-strong teaching centres. â†—Medical Training (Prioritisation) Bill â€” UK Parliament Bills (introduced 13 Jan 2026).

Risks & constraints: Risk: delivery Placement and educator capacity; Risk: finance long-term funding; Risk: governance overlapping mandates across DHSC, NHS England and universities. â†—Medical Training (Prioritisation) Bill â€” UK Parliament Bills (introduced 13 Jan 2026).

2.7 â€” Migration, Borders and Asylum

Scope: System throughput; irregular migration; legal routes; enforcement.

Policy Group Notes

  • Crossings volume and backlog metrics: track quarterly to see if (a) the backlog programme and (b) the France pilot reduce arrivals and hotel use. [links: Backlog Recovery; UKâ€“France Pilot]
  • Appeals and tribunals: the bestâ€‘laid enforcement and backlog plans still depend on hearing capacity; monitor Ministry of Justice performance and any reforms. [links: Backlog Recovery; Borders & Enforcement Bill]
  • Local impacts: safe routes rely on councils for housing and schools; outcome quality depends on local integration grants and capacity. [links: Safe and Legal Routes]
  • Legal safeguards: sanctions and removals must balance speed with fairness; transparent guidance and published safeguards reduce legal risk. [links: Border Security Command; Removals & Returns]

Border Security Command & Smuggling Sanctions

Status: programme Lead: Home Office/National Crime Agency Start: 2024-08 Horizon: medium

Intent (plain language): Create a single command to coordinate police, Border Force and the crime agency against peopleâ€‘smuggling gangs, and cut their money flows with targeted sanctions. â†—GOV.UK â€” Restoring Control Over the Immigration System (Command Paper, 2024).

Mechanism(s): Administrative reorganisation (new command); sanctions regime that can freeze assets and ban travel for named facilitators; joint tasking with French counterparts on beaches and in the Channel. â†—UK to launch world first sanctions regime to snare people smugglers travelling upstream.

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: proven Area: migration Horizon: short Named smugglers designated; first assets and accounts frozen. â†—People smugglers to have assets frozen and be banned from UK.
  • Impact: likely Area: migration Horizon: medium Closer cooperation improves arrests and boat seizures on both sides of the Channel. â†—New UK-French action to go after smuggler gangs.
  • Unknown Longâ€‘run deterrent effect on crossings volume. â†—How the government can design better asylum policy.

Costs & funding: Command staffed largely from existing agencies; sanctions administration funded from HO baseline. â†—New investment for Border Security Command.

Distributional effects: Focuses enforcement on organised criminals, not genuine refugees; minimal direct impact on communities except for fewer criminal operations in coastal areas. â†—Border Security, Asylum and Immigration Bill.

Risks & constraints: Risk: legal Evidence standards for sanctions; Risk: delivery dataâ€‘sharing with partners; Risk: political expectations vs measurable reductions. â†—The Global Irregular Migration and Trafficking in Persons Sanctions Regulations 2025.

Timeline & milestones: Command stood up (2024 Q3); first sanctions designations (2025 Q1â€“Q2); joint operations scaleâ€‘up through 2025. â†—UK brings forward worldâ€™s first sanctions regime to smash the gangs responsible for irregular migration.

Outcome score: +1 â€” Coherent focus on gangs; success hinges on crossâ€‘border intelligence and rapid legal processes.

Asylum Backlog Recovery Programme

Status: programme Lead: Home Office Start: 2024-08 Horizon: short

Intent (plain language): Reduce the number of undecided asylum cases by hiring and training more decisionâ€‘makers, using simpler forms for clear cases, and speeding up interviews. â†—Tribunal system reforms to speed up asylum decisions.

Mechanism(s): Hiring surge; simplified questionnaires for wellâ€‘founded nationalities; triage; extra interview capacity (evenings/weekends). â†—How can the UK make better asylum policy?

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: proven Area: migration Horizon: short Pending cases cut significantly from the 2023 peak; faster decisions per quarter. â†—Home Office â€” How many cases are in the UK asylum system? (year ending June 2025).
  • Impact: likely Area: migration Horizon: short Fewer people in hotels as cases move to a decision. â†—Home Office â€” How many people receive asylum support? (year ending June 2025).
  • Unknown Appeals system throughput and tribunal capacity. â†—Surge to clear asylum decisions backlog means appeals system struggling to cope.

Costs & funding: Recruitment and overtime funded within Home Office settlement; tribunal funding pressures remain. â†—How many cases are in the UK asylum system?

Distributional effects: Faster grants move people to lawful work and housing; faster refusals enable removals or voluntary returns. â†—Reforming the asylum system. House of Commons Library briefing.

Risks & constraints: Risk: delivery Recruiting experienced caseworkers; Risk: legal quality of decisions leading to appeals; Risk: data-gap incomplete realâ€‘time stats across regions. â†—The asylum and protection transformation programme. National Audit Office.

Timeline & milestones: Decision surge (2024 Q4â€“2025 Q2); next target to clear legacy cohorts; tribunal reform proposals due 2025. â†—Restoring Control Over the Immigration System.

Outcome score: +1 â€” Visible progress on throughput; sustained improvement depends on appeals capacity and quality assurance.

UKâ€“France â€œone in, one outâ€ Returns Pilot

Status: programme Lead: No.10/Home Office Start: 2025-07 Horizon: short

Intent (plain language): Return a small number of people who arrive across the Channel to France, while Britain takes the same number from France by a safe legal route (family ties first). â†—Reuters â€” UK to start implementing migrant returns deal with France within days (4 Aug 2025).

Mechanism(s): Bilateral administrative agreement; fastâ€‘track processing at arrival sites; French reception and UK familyâ€‘reunion pathway. â†—UK-France treaty targeting illegal crossings comes into force.

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: proven Area: migration Horizon: short First detentions and scheduled returns completed under the pilot. â†—Migrant return flights to France set to start next week.
  • Impact: likely Area: migration Horizon: short Small but symbolic returns restore a path blocked since leaving the EU. â†—Unauthorised migration: UK returns agreements with other countries.
  • Unknown Scaleâ€‘up feasibility and deterrent effect at current arrival volumes. â†—Migration Observatory â€” Channel crossings: briefings and tracker.

Costs & funding: Within existing HO operations; some accommodation and casework costs for legal route entrants. â†—Border Security, Asylum and Immigration Bill.

Distributional effects: Reduces incentives for dangerous crossings for some; creates a controlled route for people with family in the UK. â†—Understanding asylum seeker and asylum-route refugee vulnerabilities, needs, and support (2022).

Risks & constraints: Risk: delivery Capacity limits (initially dozens per week); Risk: legal individual challenges; Risk: political French and UK domestic pressures. â†—One In, One Out: UK must address human rights concerns over new migration pilot scheme.

Timeline & milestones: Pilot launch (2025 Q3); review point after first months; decision on expansion with EU partners in 2026. â†—Unauthorised migration: Timeline and overview of UK-French cooperation.

Outcome score: +1 â€” Useful proofâ€‘ofâ€‘concept; impact depends on scaling and parallel safeâ€‘route capacity.

Status: programme Lead: Home Office/FCDO Start: ongoing Horizon: medium

Intent (plain language): Expand controlled ways to reach the UK without using smugglersâ€”UNâ€‘led resettlement and family reunionâ€”so people with strong claims can travel safely. â†—GOV.UK â€” Command Paper: Restoring Control Over the Immigration System (resettlement scheme).

  • Unknown Demand vs capacity, especially for Afghans and other highâ€‘need groups. â†—ICMPD, EU Agency for Asylum, partners tackle humanitarian admission, safe resettlement, and legal pathways for Afghans in Europe.

Outcome score: +2 â€” Ethical, rulesâ€‘based routes that undercut smugglers when combined with enforcement.

Asylum and Returns Policy Statement â€” â€œRestoring Order and Controlâ€

Status: policy-statement Lead: Home Office/No.10 Start: 2025-11 Horizon: medium

Status: programme Lead: Home Office Start: 2024-09 Horizon: short

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: proven Area: migration Horizon: short Enforced removals and voluntary returns up from pandemic lows; foreign national offender removals up yearâ€‘onâ€‘year. â†—GOV.UK â€” Immigration system statistics: year ending June 2025 (summary) â€”
  • Impact: likely Area: migration Horizon: short Deterrence among cohorts with weak claims; faster case closure reduces costs. â†—Unauthorised migration: UK returns agreements with other countries.
  • Unknown Sustaining capacity given legal challenges and escort staffing.

Costs & funding: Flight and detention costs within HO envelope; some recoveries via bilateral costâ€‘sharing. â†—The aid budget and support for refugees in the UK, 2022 to 2025.

Distributional effects: Public safety benefit from deporting serious offenders; limited community impact elsewhere. â†—Sentencing Bill: foreign national offenders factsheet.

Risks & constraints: Risk: legal judicial review and countryâ€‘ofâ€‘origin barriers; Risk: delivery escorts, detention space; Risk: political highâ€‘profile cases.

Timeline & milestones: Quarterly removal targets; new readmission MoUs; returns pipeline tied to backlog decisions. â†—Returns from the UK and illegal working activity from 5 July 2024 to 4 January 2025.

Outcome score: +1 â€” Activity levels improving; legal and capacity bottlenecks remain the main brake.

Border Security, Asylum and Immigration Act 2025 (postâ€‘Rwanda framework)

Status: enacted Lead: Home Office Start: 2025-12 Horizon: medium

Intent (plain language): Replace the previous governmentâ€™s Rwanda plan with a lawful approach: tougher action on gangs, targeted removals, more safe routes, and faster case handling. Clarify how â€œinadmissibilityâ€ and appeals will work without offshoring. â†—Border Security, Asylum and Immigration Bill 2025: overarching impact assessment.

Mechanism(s): Primary legislation to tidy the statute book after Rwanda repeal; amendments on appeals timelines; modern slavery referral rules; new offences for facilitation; with commencement and operational guidance determining real-world effect. â†—Understanding the Border Security, Asylum and Immigration Bill. â†—Border Security, Asylum and Immigration Act 2025. â†—Border Security, Asylum and Immigration Act receives Royal Assent â€” GOV.UK (2 Dec 2025).

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: likely Area: migration Horizon: medium Clearer rules speed up decisions and removals; reduce hotel use. â†—Universal Credit and Personal Independence Payment Bill 2024-25: Progress of the bill (House of Commons Library briefing, July 8, 2025).
  • Impact: hypothetical Area: migration Horizon: medium Balanced systemâ€”firm on illegal entry, fair on refugeesâ€”improves compliance and trust. â†—Why government should introduce an annual Migration Plan.
  • Unknown Court interpretation of revised timelines and protections. â†—Border Security, Asylum and Immigration Bill - Explanatory Notes.

Costs & funding: Marginal legislative and system change costs; savings if hotel use falls and cases close sooner. â†—UK's asylum hotel bill down 30%, government says.

Distributional effects: More certainty for applicants; clearer protection for trafficking victims while limiting abuse of the system. â†—Temporary permission to stay: considerations for victims of human trafficking or slavery (accessible).

Risks & constraints: Risk: legal compatibility with international obligations; Risk: political pressure from both sides; Risk: delivery IT/process readiness. â†—How the government can design better asylum policy.

Timeline & milestones: Royal Assent Dec 2025; commencement via secondary rules; operational guidance to follow through 2026. â†—Border Security, Asylum and Immigration Act 2025. â†—Border Security, Asylum and Immigration Act receives Royal Assent â€” GOV.UK (2 Dec 2025).

Outcome score: +1 â€” Sensible cleanâ€‘up and process fixes; results depend on delivery and court rulings.

Deprivation of Citizenship Orders (Effect during Appeal) Act 2025

Status: enacted Lead: Home Office Start: 2025-10 Horizon: medium

Intent (plain language): Change how deprivation of citizenship orders operate during appeal periods, closing a perceived legal â€œgapâ€ in the effect of orders while challenges are ongoing. â†—Deprivation of Citizenship Orders (Effect during Appeal) Act 2025.

Mechanism(s): Primary legislation clarifying the effect/timing of deprivation orders during appeals (operational impact depends on Home Office guidance and court interpretation). â†—Deprivation of Citizenship Orders (Effect during Appeal) Act 2025.

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: likely Area: security Horizon: medium Strengthens governmentâ€™s hand in high-risk nationality cases by reducing delay/uncertainty during appeals. â†—Deprivation of Citizenship Orders (Effect during Appeal) Act 2025.
  • Unknown Rights and fairness impacts, including how courts interpret safeguards and proportionality. â†—Deprivation of Citizenship Orders (Effect during Appeal) Act 2025.

Costs & funding: Administrative and legal casework costs; depends on volume of deprivation cases and litigation. â†—Deprivation of Citizenship Orders (Effect during Appeal) Act 2025.

Distributional effects: Impacts a small number of cases, but with high consequence for affected individuals and families. â†—Deprivation of Citizenship Orders (Effect during Appeal) Act 2025.

Risks & constraints: Risk: legalRisk: rights Litigation and reputational risk; need for robust evidence standards and published safeguards. â†—Deprivation of Citizenship Orders (Effect during Appeal) Act 2025.

Timeline & milestones: Royal Assent Oct 2025; operational guidance and case law will clarify effects over time. â†—Deprivation of Citizenship Orders (Effect during Appeal) Act 2025.

Outcome score: 0 â€” Potentially strengthens national security posture, but fairness and legal safeguards are central.

Visa and Settlement Rule Tightenings (implemented/queued)

Status: administrative Lead: Home Office Start: 2025-12 Horizon: medium

Intent (plain language): Tighten eligibility and pathways across visas and settlement to reduce inflows and increase compliance, with knockâ€‘on effects for employers, universities and families. â†—House of Commons Library â€” Changes to the UK visa and settlement rules (2025).

Mechanism(s): Immigration Rules changes and administrative guidance (some in force, others announced/queued), with impacts depending on timing, exemptions and enforcement. â†—House of Commons Library â€” Changes to the UK visa and settlement rules (2025).

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: likely Area: migration Horizon: medium Tighter rules can reduce some visa volumes and slow settlement routes, with higher friction for sponsors and applicants. â†—House of Commons Library â€” Changes to the UK visa and settlement rules (2025).
  • Unknown Net effect on universities and regional economies, and whether changes shift routes rather than reduce total flows. â†—House of Commons Library â€” Changes to the UK visa and settlement rules (2025).

Costs & funding: Sponsor compliance costs; Home Office processing and enforcement costs; potential fiscal effects via tax receipts and tuition export earnings. â†—House of Commons Library â€” Changes to the UK visa and settlement rules (2025).

Distributional effects: Concentrated impacts on sectors reliant on skilled visas and on universities; family-route impacts depend on thresholds and exemptions. â†—House of Commons Library â€” Changes to the UK visa and settlement rules (2025).

Risks & constraints: Risk: economyRisk: delivery Skills shortages and reduced international student income; processing capacity; legal challenges in edge cases. â†—House of Commons Library â€” Changes to the UK visa and settlement rules (2025).

Timeline & milestones: Commons Library briefing documents 2025 rule changes and planned steps; track effective dates as they come into force. â†—House of Commons Library â€” Changes to the UK visa and settlement rules (2025).

Outcome score: 0 â€” Could improve control optics, but risks to growth and services depend on design and calibration.

2.8 â€” Digital, Data and AI

Scope: Data portability that lets people and small firms share their data safely to save money or get better deals; trusted digital identity to prove who you are online; an institute that tests powerful AI models before they go live; modern product safety for online marketplaces; and the Online Safety Act implementation stance (with a separate deep-dive report linked elsewhere).

Policy Group Notes

  • Measured benefits from pilots (fraud reduction, easier switching, SME finance) should be surfaced in simple, human terms (e.g., â€œminutes saved,â€ â€œÂ£ saved per yearâ€), not just technical metrics. â†—DSIT â€” Smart Data: call for evidence.
  • AI testing results should explain the risk in plain English (e.g., â€œthe model could be tricked into explaining harmful stepsâ€), and show what changed after fixes. â†—GOV.UK â€” International AI Safety Report 2025.
  • Data portability should avoid jargon (â€œdownload your dataâ€ vs â€œAPI accessâ€) and give easy routes for people with lower digital confidence. â†—Enabling the use of digital identities in the UK.
  • Product safety updates should spell out whatâ€™s new for shoppers (â€œmarketplaces must remove unsafe goods quickly and keep devices updatedâ€). â†—OPSS â€” Online marketplace code of practice.

Data (Use & Access) Act 2025 â€” Smart Data and Digital Identity

Status: enacted Lead: DSIT/OfDIA Start: 2025-06 Horizon: medium

Intent (plain language): Give government the legal tools to switch on â€œSmart Dataâ€ schemes across sectors so people can share their own data (like energy use or telecoms bills) with trusted apps to get a better deal, and put the UKâ€™s digital identity trust framework on a firm legal footing so people can prove who they are online easily and safely. â†—Data (Use and Access) Act 2025.

Mechanism(s): Primary legislation that (1) lets ministers create sector-specific Smart Data regulations; (2) establishes a statutory Digital Verification Services regime with a government-run register of certified identity providers (via the Office for Digital Identities and Attributes, OfDIA); and (3) brings other data enablers like the National Underground Asset Register into scope. â†—Data (Use and Access) Act 2025. â†—Office for Digital Identities and Attributes â€” Digital Verification Services register/trust mark.

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: proven Area: digital Horizon: short Act received Royal Assent; OfDIA preparing the statutory provider register and trust mark. â†—Data (Use and Access) Act 2025. â†—Office for Digital Identities and Attributes â€” Digital Verification Services register/trust mark.
  • Impact: likely Area: digital Horizon: medium First Smart Data schemes (energy/telecoms) expected via secondary rules from 2025â€“26, building on pilots that cut hassle and fraud. â†—DSIT â€” Smart Data Roadmap (publication). â†—DSIT â€” Smart Data: call for evidence.
  • Unknown Final design choices (privacy safeguards, redress, inclusion) will be set in sector regulations; real-world uptake depends on user-friendly services. â†—ICO â€” Right to data portability (detailed guidance).

Costs & funding: Setup and oversight costs for government and regulators; compliance costs for firms; expected net savings for households/SMEs from easier switching and lower fraud. â†—The Data Use and Access Act 2025 (DUAA) - what does it mean for organisations?

Distributional effects: Benefits everyday users and small businesses by putting them in control of their data; risk of excluding people without smartphones or formal ID unless inclusion measures are built in. â†—Enabling the use of digital identities in the UK.

Risks & constraints: Risk: securityRisk: deliveryRisk: legal Getting consent, security and liability right; avoiding vendor lock-in; making data standards interoperable across sectors. â†—The 6 main issues with vendor consolidation.

Timeline & milestones: 2025-06 Royal Assent; late-2025 OfDIA register and trust mark go live; 2026 first sector schemes begin (energy/telecoms). â†—DSIT â€” Smart Data Roadmap (publication).

Outcome score: +2 â€” Clear enabler for pro-consumer, pro-competition services if implemented with strong safeguards.

Smart Data Schemes â€” Energy, Telecoms and Finance roll-out

Status: programme Lead: DSIT with Ofgem/Ofcom/FCA Start: 2024-11 Horizon: medium

Intent (plain language): Turn the new legal powers into practical schemes that let people share their usage and billing data (with permission) to find cheaper tariffs, get fairer deals, and access green or growth finance more easily. â†—DSIT â€” Smart Data opportunities in digital markets.

Mechanism(s): Pilots (e.g., â€œPerseusâ€ linking business smart meter data to banks for green loans), consultations, and then sector regulations that mandate secure data-sharing pipes between companies and certified third parties. A cross-sector Smart Data Group coordinates standards and timing. â†—Perseus linking business smart meter data to banks for green loans, consultations, and then sector regulations. â†—DSIT â€” Smart data and price transparency schemes: discussion paper (PDF).

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: proven Area: energy Horizon: short Early energy Smart Data services already help hundreds of thousands compare tariffs or plan retrofits, cutting admin time for households and SMEs. â†—Potential new smart data scheme to drive innovation and support consumers in the energy market.
  • Impact: likely Area: digital Horizon: medium Standardised data access in telecoms and banking expected to reduce bill shock and fraud, and boost competition. â†—DSIT â€” Smart Data: call for evidence.
  • Unknown Real savings depend on consumer uptake, app quality, and regulator enforcement of standards. â†—CMA proposes next steps for improving mobile platforms in the UK.

Costs & funding: Integration and compliance costs for providers; expected net benefits through reduced search costs, fewer errors, and better credit decisions. â†—The Data Use and Access Act 2025 (DUAA) - what does it mean for organisations?

Risks & constraints: Risk: deliveryRisk: security Interoperability across legacy IT; consistent, secure consent flows; avoiding â€œdark patterns.â€ â†—ICO â€” Right to data portability (detailed guidance).

Timeline & milestones: 2024â€“25 pilots and consultations; 2026 first mandatory schemes switch on; 2027+ expansion to more sectors. â†—DSIT â€” Smart Data Roadmap (publication).

Outcome score: +2 â€” Likely to save money and time at scale if the pipes and protections are done well.

UK AI Safety/Security Institute â€” testing models before deployment

Status: programme Lead: DSIT/AISI Start: 2024-11 Horizon: medium

Intent (plain language): Test powerful AI models for dangerous capabilities (like helping with cybercrime or bio-harm) before and after they are released, publish methods and results, and set shared standards with partners overseas. â†—GOV.UK â€” International AI Safety Report 2025.

Mechanism(s): Government institute with an expert team that runs standard evaluations, â€œred teamâ€ tests under non-disclosure agreements with labs, and open-sources its testing toolkit (e.g., â€œInspectâ€) so others can replicate checks. Partnerships with peer bodies in the US, EU and Canada. â†—AISI â€” Inspect testing framework (openâ€‘source). â†—AISI â€” MOUs with US/Canada.

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: proven Area: ai Horizon: short First test reports published; Inspect tool released; at least one frontier model was red-teamed before launch. â†—GOV.UK â€” International AI Safety Report 2025. â†—AISI â€” Inspect testing framework (openâ€‘source).
  • Impact: likely Area: ai Horizon: medium Pre-deployment testing becomes standard for leading models and informs procurement and safety guidance. â†—International AI Safety Report 2025.
  • Unknown How quickly tests must evolve to keep pace with new model capabilities; how findings translate into enforceable guardrails. â†—International AI Safety Report 2025.

Costs & funding: Public funding for staff, secure compute and partnerships; relatively modest compared with the potential costs of unsafe deployment. â†—Engines of AI primed to accelerate new breakthroughs, economic growth, and transform the UK into an AI maker.

Distributional effects: Benefits users and public services by reducing risk; some compliance and disclosure costs for AI developers. â†—GOV.UK â€” International AI Safety Report 2025.

Risks & constraints: Risk: deliveryRisk: access Continuous access to cutting-edge models; staying technically ahead; coordination with international regulators. â†—AISI â€” MOUs with US/Canada.

Timeline & milestones: 2024 launch; 2025 first evaluations, tool release, and US/Canada partnerships; 2026 common evaluation baselines agreed with partners. â†—International AI Safety Report 2025.

Outcome score: +2 â€” Practical safety testing is now happening; impact grows as standards embed across the industry.

Public-Sector Digital Identity â€” trusted checks for everyday life

Status: programme Lead: DSIT/OfDIA/Cabinet Office Start: 2025-06 Horizon: medium

Intent (plain language): Let people prove they are who they say they are online (for example, to rent a flat, verify age, or start a job) using certified apps that meet government standards, without repeatedly scanning paperwork or sharing more data than needed. â†—Office for Digital Identities and Attributes â€” Digital Verification Services register/trust mark.

Mechanism(s): Statutory Digital Verification Services: government certifies providers, publishes a register and trust mark, and allows controlled data checks to verify identity attributes (such as age or right to work). Services must be private by default and consent-based. â†—Data (Use and Access) Act 2025. â†—UK digital identity and attributes trust framework gamma (0.4).

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: proven Area: digital Horizon: short The Act moves digital identity into a statutory Digital Verification Services (DVS) regime; the trust framework becomes the baseline for a certification + trustâ€‘mark model that services can build to. â†—Data (Use and Access) Act 2025. â†—UK digital identity and attributes trust framework gamma (0.4). â†—Office for Digital Identities and Attributes â€” Digital Verification Services register/trust mark.
  • Impact: likely Area: economy Horizon: medium Faster, safer onboarding across renting, hiring and payments reduces fraud and admin burden. â†—Data (Use and Access) Act 2025: Explanatory Notes.
  • Unknown Inclusion and accessibility outcomes; cross-border recognition with other countriesâ€™ ID systems. â†—ICO â€” Right to data portability (detailed guidance).

Costs & funding: Certification and compliance costs for providers; net savings from reduced document checks and fraud for employers, landlords and users. â†—The Data Use and Access Act 2025 (DUAA) - what does it mean for organisations?

Distributional effects: Convenience gains for most users; ensure offline routes remain for those without smartphones or formal documents. â†—Enabling the use of digital identities in the UK.

Risks & constraints: Risk: securityRisk: legal Strong privacy-by-design, clear liability and robust complaint routes are essential to build trust. â†—ICO â€” Right to data portability (detailed guidance).

Timeline & milestones: Late-2025: DVS trust framework becomes the compliance baseline and certification ramps up; register opens and first providers are certified; 2026: wider adoption across renting, age checks and right-to-work flows. â†—UK digital identity and attributes trust framework gamma (0.4). â†—Office for Digital Identities and Attributes â€” Digital Verification Services register/trust mark.

Outcome score: +1 â€” High-utility public infrastructure if delivered with strong privacy, reliable tech and inclusive design.

Property (Digital Assets etc) Act 2025 â€” digital assets as personal property

Status: enacted Lead: MoJ Start: 2025-12 Horizon: medium

Intent (plain language): Reduce legal uncertainty by confirming that certain digital assets can be treated as personal property, making it easier to apply familiar rules around ownership, transfers and remedies to new forms of value. â†—Property (Digital Assets etc) Act 2025.

Mechanism(s): Primary legislation clarifying that a digital asset is not excluded from being â€œpropertyâ€ just because it is neither a physical thing nor a traditional â€œthing in actionâ€. This supports courts and practitioners in applying property concepts to digital assets in disputes and transactions. â†—Property (Digital Assets etc) Act 2025.

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: proven Area: digital Horizon: short Act passed, providing a clearer statutory basis for treating digital assets as personal property. â†—Property (Digital Assets etc) Act 2025.
  • Impact: likely Area: economy Horizon: medium Lower transaction friction and clearer dispute resolution for firms and consumers interacting with digital assets (custody, insolvency, enforcement). â†—The Law Society â€” New law recognises digital assets as property.
  • Unknown How quickly market practices, standard contracts and court decisions converge on consistent treatment across different asset types. â†—Property (Digital Assets etc) Act 2025.

Costs & funding: Minimal direct public spending; private legal/compliance work to update contracts and policies. â†—Property (Digital Assets etc) Act 2025.

Distributional effects: Benefits concentrate in sectors building on digital assets (finance, tech, legal services); downstream consumer impacts depend on market uptake and safeguards. â†—The Law Society â€” New law recognises digital assets as property.

Risks & constraints: Risk: legal Cross-border inconsistency remains a constraint for global markets; clarity on â€œpropertyâ€ does not resolve all consumer protection and regulatory questions. â†—Property (Digital Assets etc) Act 2025.

Timeline & milestones: 2025-12 Royal Assent; 2026+ impacts emerge through contract updates and litigation. â†—Property (Digital Assets etc) Act 2025.

Outcome score: +1 â€” Valuable clarity, but most benefits are indirect and depend on wider market/regulatory practice.

Mechanism(s): Ofcom codes of practice, age-assurance guidance, transparency duties and enforcement investigations; staged commencement through 2025â€“26. â†—Ofcom â€” Online Safety codes hub.

  • Impact: proven Area: safety Horizon: short First Ofcom codes published; major platforms have started rolling out age checks and content labelling in response. â†—Ofcom â€” Online Safety codes hub.

  • Impact: proven Area: safety Horizon: short First reported Online Safety Act fine (Â£1m) over age-check failures for adult content, signalling that enforcement is moving from â€œprepareâ€ to penalties. â†—Financial Times â€” First Online Safety Act fine reported (Â£1m) over age-check failures for adult content (Feb 2026).
  • Impact: likely Area: safety Horizon: medium Better child protection on mainstream platforms; risk of workarounds (VPNs) and unintended moderation effects. â†—5Rights/Joint Civil Society â€” Briefing on implementation of the Online Safety Act (Feb 2025).

Distributional effects: Stronger protections for children and parents; potential friction for adult users in age-gated services. â†—5Rights/Joint Civil Society â€” Briefing on implementation of the Online Safety Act (Feb 2025).

Risks & constraints: Risk: legalRisk: technical Encryption, cross-border services, and jurisdictional limits. â†—5Rights/Joint Civil Society â€” Briefing on implementation of the Online Safety Act (Feb 2025).

Timeline & milestones: 2025: codes laid; 2025-12: early industry compliance reporting becomes more visible; 2026-02: first reported fine; 2025â€“26: staged enforcement; 2026+: evaluation and code updates. â†—Ofcom â€” Online Safety codes hub. â†—Ofcom â€” Online safety industry bulletin (December 2025). â†—Financial Times â€” First Online Safety Act fine reported (Â£1m) over age-check failures for adult content (Feb 2026).

Outcome score: -1 â€” Important but contested; now shifting from codes into visible enforcement, with major trade-offs still in play.

English Devolution & Community Empowerment Bill

Status: bill-in-train Lead: DLUHC/Cabinet Office Start: 2025-09 Horizon: medium

Intent (plain language): Give every part of England a clear route to a mayor and deeper local powers, without years of bespoke negotiations. Set national rules so places that meet goodâ€‘governance tests automatically unlock stronger powers.

Mechanism(s): Primary legislation defining tiers of devolution, triggers to move up those tiers, and a backstop for creating combined authorities where local agreement stalls. Simplifies how funding and powers are awarded, replacing oneâ€‘off deals. â†—Devolution to local government in England. House of Commons Library briefing, 18 Mar 2025.

Key claims & evidence:

  • Impact: likely Area: devolution Horizon: medium Bill creates a uniform â€œladderâ€ of powers so established mayors can graduate to deeper fiscal and transport powers. â†—Devolution to local government in England. House of Commons Library briefing, 18 Mar 2025.

  • Unknown Timing for county areas to reach â€œestablished mayorâ€ status varies with local capacity and consent. â†—NAO â€” Levelling up funding to local government (2023).

Costs & funding: Mainly administrative changes and reâ€‘profiling of existing grants. No large new central spending line is expected at passage. â†—DLUHC â€” Budget boost for housing, local growth and remediation (Nov 2024).

Distributional effects: More control for cityâ€‘regions and counties; risk of uneven pace if smaller areas lack capacity.

Risks & constraints: Risk: deliveryRisk: political Local consent, Whitehall departments aligning on a single model, legal drafting for backstop powers. â†—IFG - Labour's Constitutional Proposals.

Outcome score: +1 â€” A clearer, rulesâ€‘based path to devolution; real impact depends on implementation speed.
